Award.AwardTitle: The unicellular origin of biological senescence: Its evolution and population dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The supported research project investigates the origin of biological aging in single-celled organisms such as bacteria. The hypothesis to be tested is that whenever bacteria accrue non-genetic damage, such as oxidized proteins, it is more advantageous for a mother cell to reproduce by allocating asymmetrically more damage to one of her two daughter cells. Because damage causes a cell to grow more slowly, the daughter receiving less damage is rejuvenated and the one receiving more is aged. The advantage of asymmetry was predicted by a theoretical analysis conducted with a computational model and it can be illustrated with an investment analogy. Consider having bank accounts A ($1,000 at 8% yearly) and B ($500 at 6% and $500 at 10%). If more money is the goal, account B has more after two years. Partitioning damage asymmetrically generates a fast and a slow growing daughter, and it is equivalent to having account B. Partitioning damage symmetrically is comparable to account A. The demonstration that bacteria age would overturn a long standing dogma in biology that aging is a characteristic of only complex and multi-cellular organisms such as humans. If bacterial aging is real, a scientific paradigm will have shifted and text books will have to be rewritten. Moreover, if aging is universal to both bacteria and humans, a common mechanism may exist and the results of this study would help guide research on aging in all organisms. If there is a common mechanism, a common solution may also exist. The fact that human aging is often also associated with oxidative damage is already a promising link.

A unicellular origin of aging does not require natural selection on groups because it is the fitness of the lineage that is maximized by the asymmetrical partitioning of damage. Two sets of experiments with the bacterium Escherichia coli will be completed to test the proposed models of aging in the supported research. First, the effect of short term variation in the level of damage experienced by a single bacterial species will be examined. Second, the degree of asymmetry will be estimated and compared for different bacterial species that have evolved over long term under high levels of damage. Damage levels will be manipulated by adding extrinsic damage agents (e.g. heat, peroxides, antibiotics, and radiation). The analyses of the theoretical models predict (i) that short term variation in damage levels causes the bacteria to transition from immortality to mortality and (ii) that long term exposure to high levels leads to the evolution of higher degrees of asymmetry. The degree of asymmetry is quantified by the asymmetry parameter in the models. The parameter is estimated by fitting the models to population data, which are the doubling or generation time of individual cells estimated by time-lapse microscopy of dividing bacterial populations. Novel insights will be attained by this robust investigation of bacterial aging providing the framework to readdress both the short-term and long-term aspects of the population dynamics and evolution, respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. The traditional view in biology was that bacteria did not experience biological aging because a mother cell divides to produce two identical daughters. At the time we started our project, a few studies were starting to show evidence for bacterial aging. This NSF award supported our effort to provide one of the more detailed studies supporting the existence of aging in the bacterium Escherichia coli. Bacterial aging occurs because a mother allocates more of her damage (for example, oxidative damage) to one of the daughters. The daughter receiving more (the old daughter) ages, while the one receiving less (the new daughter) rejuvenates. We found that when the mother partitions damage asymmetrically to her two daughters, the new and old daughter lineages age and rejuvenate to constant equilibrium growth states. In other words, the old daughter deteriorates from aging, but deterioration stops a the equilibrium state and lineage does not die. It is immortal. However, we also found that when the stressed the bacteria with heat, phototoxic light, and antibiotics the old daughter equilibrium becomes unstable and the lineage stops dividing (in other words dies). Thus, the bacteria become mortal. We believe that this transition from mortality to immortality results from the intrinsic level of damage experienced by cells. We propose that multicellular organisms are mortal because the complexity of multicellular development and growth may have required a higher energetic cost and more oxidative damage. Our results suggest that biological aging arose in unicellular organisms. Establishing the origin and causes of biological mortality may help us understand better the causes of all forms of aging, including in humans.

 Broader Impacts. We believe that the most worthy impact of our work is that it offers an easy message to promote science and research to the general public. We have given short to long presentations to students from middle school, high school, and colleges, to returning adult students, to alumni, and to mixed and general audiences. Past NSF reviewers have challenged us on whether bacterial aging, stable equilibria, and phase plots can be easily communicated. Our response was come to our talks. To illustrate, our short version, which is quite popular with pre-college students, is a talk called “How smart are bacteria?” We ask the students whether $1000 at 8% interest generates more money than a pool of $500 at 6% and $500 at 10%. After they figure it out, we tell them that bacteria do the same by partitioning damage asymmetrically to its two daughters. We then show them our time-lapse videos of dividing bacteria and provide them some doubling time data. In ten minutes we have shown them the value of math, a hypothesis, an experiment, and data. In longer talks, we develop the ideas more fully, add more math, introduce mortality and immortality, discuss how bacterial aging was not recognized and how science adjusts in the face of new evidence. Students beam of joyful comprehension afterwards. At the end we always return to emphasizing the beauty of science and encouraging them to consider a career in science. We were recently fortunate to be invited to give a talk at the Laguna Art Museum (LAM) on Science and Nature. We found the visit to be extremely exciting, especially after the curators, resident artists, and attendees felt that the patterns formed by our growing bacterial cells in our time-lapse videos reminded them of their own artworks. We are now working on establishing a partnership with LAM to start a new seires in Science and Art.
